sp.p: Aye, and your mistresses, too, i' faith, and from genuine GreeceGenuine Greece: Perhaps in contradistinction to Sicily, which was only colonized by Greeks.; for one of them was born at Athens of free-born parents.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: What is it I hear from you?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: That she pointing to PALÆSTRA was born at Athens, a free-born woman.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: to TRACHALIO. Prithee is she a countrywoman of mine?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Are you not a Cyrenian?

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: No; born at Athens in Attica, bred and educated there.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Prithee, aged sir, do protect your countrywomen.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: aside. O daughter, when I look on her, separated from me you remind me of my miseries: aloud she who was lost by me when three years old; now, if she is living, she's just about as tall, I'm sure, as she. Pointing to PALÆSTRA.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I paid the money down for these two, to their owners, of whatever country they were. What matters it to me whether they were born at Athens or at Thebes, so long as they are rightfully in servitude as my slaves?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: it so, you impudent fellow? What, are you, a cat prowling after maidens, to be keeping children here kidnapped from their parents and destroying them in your disgraceful calling? But as for this other one, I really don't know what her country is; I only know that she's more deserving than yourself, you most abominable rascal.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Are these women your property?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Come to the trial, then, which of the two according to his back is the more truthful; if you don't bear more complimentsCompliments: "Offerumenta," according to Festus, signified an offering to the Gods; and as these were fixed to the walls of the Temples, Trachalio calls the lashes of the scourge or rod, when applied to the back of the delinquent slave, by the same term. upon your back than any ship of warShip of war: "Longa navis." Literally, "a long ship." Ships of war were thus called by the Greeks. has nails, then I'm the greatest of liars. Afterwards, do you examine mine, when I've examined yours; if it shall not prove to be so untouched, that any leather flask makerLeather flask maker: "Ampullarius." "A maker of ampullæ,' or leather bottles. They were of a big-bellied form, with a narrow neck. will say that it is a hide most capital and most sound for the purposes of his business, what reason is there why I shouldn't mangle you with stripes, even till you have your belly full? Why do you stare at them? If you touch them I'll tear your eyes out.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Yet notwithstanding, although you forbid me to do so, I'll at once carry them off both together with me.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: What will you do?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I'll bring Vulcan; he is an enemy to VenusAn enemy to Venus: In so saying, he alludes to the intrigue of Venus with Mars, which was discovered by the device of Vulcan, her injured husband. For the story, see the Metamorphoses of Ovid, B. 4, l. 73, and the Art of Love, B. 2, l. 562.. Goes towards DÆMONES' cottage.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Whither is he going?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: calling at the door. Hallo! Is there anybody here? Hallo! I say.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: If you touch the door, that very instant, upon my faith, you shall get a harvest upon your face with fists for your pitchforksFists for your pitchforks: "Mergis pugneis." Echard, in his translation, explains this: "As they lift up their pitchforks to heap corn, so will I lift up my fists, and heap a whole harvest of cuffs on your face." "Merga' means 'a pitchfork;" and, according to Festus, it was so called from its resemblance when dipped into the hay to the action of the "mergus," or "didapper when dipping into the sea,.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: We keep no fire, we live upon dried figs.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: I'll find the fire, if only I have the opportunity of kindling it upon your head.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Faith, I'll go somewhere to look for some fire.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: What, when you've found it?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I'll be making a great fire here.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: What, to be burningTo be burning: Festus tells us that "humanum" was a "mortuary sacrifice," or "offering to the dead." In his question, therefore, Dæmones inplies a wish to know whether Labrax is about to put an end to himself. It was allowable to drive away those who fled to the altar by the agency of fire. a mortuary sacrifice for yourself?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: No, but I'll burn both of these alive here upon the altar.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: I'd like that. For, by my troth, I'll forthwith seize you by the head and throw you into the fire, and, half-roasted, I'll throw you out as food for the great birds. Aside. When I come to a consideration of it with myself, this is that ape, that wanted to take away those swallows from the nest against my will, as I was dreaming in my sleep.

sp.speaker: TPACH.
sp.p: Aged sir, do you know what I request of you? That you will protect these females and defend them from violence, until I fetch my master.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Go look for your master, and fetch him here.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: But don't let him----

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: At his own extreme peril, if he touches them, or if he attempts to do so.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Take care.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Due care is taken; do you be off.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: And watch him too, that he doesn't go away anywhere. For we have promised either to give the executioner a great talent, or else to produce this fellow this very day.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Do you only be off. I'll not let him get away, while you are absent.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I'll be back here soon. (Exit TRACHALIO.)

div2.stage: DÆMONES, LABRAX, PALÆSTRA, AMPELISCA, and SERVANTS.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: to LABRAX, who is struggling with the SERVANTS. Which, you Procurer, had you rather do, be quiet with a thrashing, or e'en as it is, without the thrashing, if you had the choice?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Old fellow, I don't care a straw for what you say. My own women, in fact, I shall drag away this instant from the altar by the hair, in spite of yourself, and Venus, and supreme Jove.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Just touch them.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: going towards them I' troth, I surely will touch them.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Just come then; only approach this way.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Only bid both those fellows, then, to move away from there.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: On the contrary, they shall move towards you.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I' faith, for my own part, I don't think so.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: If they do move nearer to you, what will you do?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I'll retire. But, old fellow, if ever I catch you in the city, never again, upon my faith, shall any one call me a Procurer, if I don't give you some most disagreable sport.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Do what you threaten. But now, in the meantime, if you do touch them, a heavy punishment shall be inflicted on you.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: How heavy, in fact?

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Just as much as is sufficient for a Procurer.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: These threats of yours I don't value one straw; I certainly shall seize them both this instant without your leave.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Just touch them.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: By my troth, I surely will touch them.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: You will touch them, but do you know with what result? Go then, Turbalio, with all haste, and bring hither from out of the house two cudgels.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Cudgels?

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Aye, good ones; make haste speedily. TURBALIO goes in. I'll let you have a reception this day in proper style, as you are deserving of.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: aside. Alas! cursedly unfortunate. I lost my headpiece in the ship; it would now have been handy for me, if it had been saved. To DÆMONES. May I at least address these women?

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: You may not * * * * * TURBALIO enters bringing two cudgels. Well now, by my faith, look, the cudgel-man is coming very opportunely here.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: aside. By my troth, this surely is a tingling for my ears.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Come, Sparax, do you take this other cudgel. Giving him one. Come, take your stand, one on one side, the other on one other. Take your stations both of you. They stand with lifted cudgels on each side of he altar. Just so. Now then attend to me: if, i' faith, that fellow there should this day touch these women with his finger against their inclination, if you don't give him a receptionTheir inclination--a reception: "Invitos--invitassitis." He here plays upon the resemblance of the words "invitos," signifying "against their will," and "invito," being a verb signifying "to invite," and admitting of much the same equivocal use as our expression, "to give a warm reception to." with these cudgels even to that degree that he shan't know which way he is to get home, you are undone, both of you. If he shall call for any one, do you make answer to this fellow in their stead. But if he himself shall attempt to get away from here, that instant, as hard a you can, lay on to his legs with your sticks.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Are they not even to allow me to go away from here?

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: I've said sufficient. And when that servant comes here with his master, he that has gone to fetch his master, do you at once go home. Attend to this with great diligence, will you. DÆMONES goes into his house.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: O rare, by my troth, the Temple here is surely changed all of a sudden; this is now the Temple of HerculesTemple of Hercules: Seeing the servants with their cudgels, he is reminded of Hercules, who was thus depicted, and was called by the Poets "Claviger." which was that of Venus before; in such fashion has the old fellow planted two statues here with clubs. I' faith, I don't know now whither in the world I shall fly from here; so greatly are they both raging now against me, both land and sea. Palæstra!

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: What do you want?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Away with you, there is a misunderstanding between us; that, indeed, is not my PalæstraNot my Palæstra: Echard, borrowing the notion from Madame Dacier, has the following Note on this passage: "This 'Palæstra' was a place of public exercise, over the gate of which was a statue of Hercules, with an inscription 'Palæstra;' now Labrax, finding this stout fellow with his club, whom before he had compared to Hercules, answering instead of Palæstra, he wittily alludes to that statue, and says that that Palæstra was none of his." Thornton appears to be right in considering this a far-fetched conceit on the part of the fair Commentatress. that answers. Harkye, Ampelisca.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Beware of a mishap, will you.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: aside. So far as they can, the worthless fellows advise me rightly enough. Aloud. But, harkye, I ask you, whether it is any harm to you for me to come nearer to these women?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Why none at all to ourselves.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Will there be any harm to myself?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: None at all, if you only take care.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: What is it that I'm to take care against?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Why, look you, against a heavy mishap.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Troth now, prithee, do let me approach them.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Approach them, if you like.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I' faith, obligingly done; I return you thanks, I'll go nearer to them. Approaches them.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Do you stand there on the spot, where you are. Drags him to his place, with the cudgel over his head.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: aside. By my faith, I've come scurvily off in many ways. Still, I'm resolved to get the better of them this day by constantly besieging them.

div2.stage: Enter PLESIDIPPUS and TRACHALIO, at a distance, on the other side of the stage.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: And did the Procurer attempt by force and violence to drag my mistress away from the altar of Venus?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Even so.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Why didn't you kill him on the instant?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I hadn't a sword.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: You should have taken either a stick or a stone.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: What! ought I to have pelted this most villanous fellow with stones like a dog? * * * * * * * * *

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: aside, on seeing them. By my troth, but I'm undone now; see, here's Plesidippus; he'll be sweeping me away altogether this moment with the dust.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Were the damsels sitting on the altar even then when you set out to come to me?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Yes, and now they are sitting in the same place.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Who is now protecting them there?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Some old gentleman, I don't know who, a neighbour of the Temple of Venus--he gave very kind assistance; he is now protecting them with his servants--I committed them to his charge.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Lead me straight to the Procurer. Where is this fellow? They go towards LABRAX.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Health to you.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: I want none of your healths. Make your choice quickly, whether you lad rather be seized by your throat wrenchedSeized by your throat wrenched: "Rapin te obtorto collo." Echard has the following Note: "When any person was brought before the Prætor, they always threw his gown or cloak about his neck, and led him that way; and this was called 'rapi obtorto collo."', or be dragged along; choose whichever you please, while you may.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I wish for neither.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Be off then, Trachalio, with all speed to the sea-shore; bid those persons that I brought with me to hand over this rascal to the executioner, to come from the harbour to the city to meet me; afterwards return hither and keep guard here. I'll now drag this scoundrelly outcast to justice. (Exit TRACHALIO. Pleusicles addresses LABRAX.). Come, proceed to a court of justice.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: In what have I offended?

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Do you ask? Didn't you receive an earnest of me for this woman pointing to PALÆSTRA, and carry her off from here?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I didn't carry her off.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Why do you deny it?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Troth now, because I put her on board ship; carry her offCarry her off: There is a play or quibble here upon the words "avehere" and "provehere," "to carry away," and "to put on board ship," for the purpose of being carried away. unfortunately, I couldn't. For my part, I told you that this day I would make my appearance at the Temple of Venus; have I swerved at all from that? Am I not there?

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Plead your cause in the court of justice; here a word is enough. Follow me. They lay hold of him.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p:
calling aloud. I entreat you, my dear Charmides, do come to my rescue; I am being seized with my throat wrenched.
Enter CHARMIDES, from the Temple.

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: looking about. Who calls my name?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Do you see me how I'm being seized?

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: I see, and view it with pleasure.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Don't you venture to assist me?

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: What person is seizing you?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Young Plesidippus.

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: What you've got, put up with; 'twere better for you, with a cheerful spirit, to slink to gaol; that has befallen you which many greatly wish for for themselves.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: To find for themselves that which they are seeking.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I entreat you, do follow me.

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: You try to persuade me, just like what you are: you are being taken off to gaol, for that reason is it you entreat me to follow you?

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: to LABRAX. Do you still resist?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I'm undone.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: I trust that may prove the truth. You, my dear Palæstra and Ampelisca, do you remain here in the meanwhile, until I return hither.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: I would advise them rather to go to our house, until you return.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: I'm quite agreable; you act obligingly. The SERVANTS open the door of the cottage, and PALÆSTRA and AMPELISCA go in.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: You are thieves to me.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: How, thieves?

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Lead him along. The SERVANTS seize him.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: calling out. I pray and entreat you, Palæstra.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Follow, you hang-dog.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Guest, Charmides!

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: I am no guest of yours; I repudiate your hospitality.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: What, do you slight me in this fashion?

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: I do so; I've been drinking with you once alreadyOnce already: He alludes to the drenching he has had in the sea, by reason of his acquaintance with Labrax, and means to say that one such reception is quite sufficient for his life..

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: May the Deities confound you.

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: To that person of yours, say that. PLESIDIPPUS leads LABRAX off, followed by the SERVANTS. I do believe that men are transformed, each into a different beast. That Procurer, I guess, is transformed into a stock-doveA stock-dove: He puns upon the resemblance between the word "columbar," "a collar," into which the head was inserted by way of punishment, and "columbus," a "pigeon." The notion of preserving the pun, by using the word "stock-dove," is Echard's. The plural of the word "columbar" was also used to signify a dove-cot.; for, before long, his neck will be in the stocks. He'll to-day be building his nest in the gaol. Still, however, I'll go, that I may be his advocate,--if by my aid he may possibly be sentenced any the sooner.

div2.stage: Enter DÆMONES, from his cottage.Echard remarks that the interval between the last Act and this is filled up with Plesidippus carrying Labrax before the Prætor and his trial, an, likewise with what passes in Dæmones' house.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: to himself. 'Twas rightly done, and it is a pleasure this day for me to have given aid to these young women; I have now found some dependants, and both of them of comely looks and youthful age. But my plaguy wife is watching me in all ways, lest I should be giving any hint to the young women. But I wonder what in the world my servant Gripus is about, who went last night to the sea to fish. Troth, he had done wiser if he had slept at home; for now he throws away both his pains and his nets, seeing what a storm there now is and was last night. I'll thoroughly cook upon my fingers what he has caught to-day; so violently do I see the ocean heaving. A bell rings. But my wife's calling me to breakfast; I'll return home. She'll now be filling my ears with her silly prating. Goes into the cottage.

div2.stage: Enter GRIPUS, dragging a net enclosing a wallet, by a rope.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: to himself. These thanks do I return to Neptune, my patron, who dwells in the salt retreats, the abode of fishes, inasmuch as he has despatched me finely laden on my return from his retreats, and from his Temples, laden with most abundant booty, with safety to my boat, which in the stormy sea made me master of a singular and rich haul. In a wondrous and incredible manner has this haul turned out prosperously for me, nor yet have I this day taken a single ounce weight of fish, but only that which I am here bringing with me in my net. For when I arose in the middle of the night, and without sloth, I preferred profit to sleep and rest; in the raging tempest, I determined to try how I might lighten the poverty of my master and my own servitude, not sparing of my own exertions. Most worthless is the man that is slothful, and most detestably do I hate that kind of men. It behoves him to be vigilant who wishes to do his duty in good time; for it befits him not to be waiting until his master arouses him to his duties. For those who sleep on for the love of it, rest without profit to themselves and to their own cost. But now I, who have not been slothful, have found that for myself through which to be slothful if I should choose. Points to the wallet. This have I found in the sea to-day; whatever's in it, it's something heavy that's in it; I think it's gold that's in it. And not a single person is there my confidant in the matter. Now, Gripus, this opportunity has befallen you, that the PrætorThe Prætor: The slave about to be manumitted, or to receive his freedom, was taken before the Prætor, whose lictor laid the "vindicta" or "festuca," "the rod of liberty," on the head of the slave, on which he received his freedom. might make you a free man from among the multitude. Now, thus shall I do, this is my determination; I'll come to my master cleverly and cunningly, little by little I'll promise money for my freedom, that I may be free. Now, when I shall be free, then, in fine, I'll provide me land and housesLand and houses: Is not this wonderfully like Alnaschar's reverie in the Arabian Nights, so aptly quoted in the Spectator? and slaves: I'll carry on merchandize with large ships: among the grandees I shall be considered a grandee. Afterwards, for the sake of pleasing myself, I'll build me a ship and I'll imitate StratonicusStratonicus: He was the treasurer of Philip of Macedon and Alexander the Great, and was famed for his wealth among the Greeks, as Crassus was among the Romans., and I'll be carried about from town to town. When my greatness is far-spread, I shall fortify some great city: to that city I shall give the name of "Gripus," a memorial of my fame and exploits, and there I'll establish a mighty kingdom. I am resolving here in my mind to prepare for mighty matters. At present I'll hide this booty. But this grandee pointing to himself is about to breakfast upon vinegarUpon vinegar: He alludes to the "posca," or vinegar and water, which formed the beverage of the slaves, and which is mentioned by Palæstrio in the Miles Gloriosus, l. 836. and salt, without any good substantial meat. Gathers up the net, and drags it after him.

div2.stage: Enter TRACHALIO, in haste.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Hallo there! stop.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Why should I stop?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: While I coil up this ropeThis rope: This is the first mention of the "rudens," or "netrope," from which the Play derives its name. for you that you are dragging.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Now let it alone.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Troth, but I'll assist you. What's kindly done to worthy men, isn't thrown away.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: * * * * * There was a boisterous tempest yesterday; no fish have I, young man; don't you be supposing I have. Don't you see that I'm carrying my dripping net without the scaly race?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I' faith, I'm not wishing for fish so much as I am in need of your conversation.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Then, whoever you are, you are worrying me to death with your annoyance.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: takes hold of him. I'll not allow you to go away from here; stop.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Take you care of a mishap, if you please; but why the plague are you dragging me back?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Listen.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: I won't listen.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: But, upon my faith, you shall listen.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Nay but, another time, tell me what you want.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Come now, it's worth your while at once to hear what I want to tell you.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Say on, whatever it is.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: See whether any person is following near us. Looks back. GRIP. Why, what reason is there that it should matter to me?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So it is; but can you give me some good advice?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What's the business? Only tell me.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I'll tell you; keep silence; if only you'll give me your word that you won't prove treacherous to me.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: I do give you my word; I'll be true to you, whoever you are.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Listen. I saw a person commit a theft; I knew the owner to whom that same property belonged. Afterwards I came myself to the thief, and I made him a proposal in these terms: "I know the person on whom that theft was committed; now if you are ready to give me half, I'll not make a discovery to the owner." He didn't even give me an answer. What is it fair should be given me out of it? Half, I trust you will say.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Aye, even more; but unless he gives it you, I think it ought to be told to the owner.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I'll act on your advice. Now give me your attention; for it is to yourself all this relates.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What has been done by me?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: pointing at the wallet. I've known the person for a long time to whom that wallet belongs.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: And in what manner it was lost.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: But I know in what manner it was found; and I know the person who found it, and who is now the owner. That, i' faith, is not a bit the more your matter than it is my own. I know the person to whom it now belongs; you, the person to whom it formerly belonged. This shall no individual get away from me; don't you be expecting to get it in a hurry.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: If the owner comes, shan't he get it away?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: That you mayn't be mistaken, no born person is there that's owner of this but my own self--who took this in my own fishing.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Was it really so?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Which fish in the sea will you say "is my own?" When I catch them, if indeed I do catch them, they are my own; as my own I keep them. They are not claimed as having a right to freedomClaimed as having a right to freedom: "Manu asserere" was "to assert" or "claim the liberty of a slave by action at law." Gripus applies the term to the fish of the sea, and means to say that when he catches them, he sells them as his own "venales," or "slaves." nor does any person demand a share in them. In the market I sell them all openly as my own wares. Indeed, the sea is, surely, common to all persons.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I agree to that; prithee, then, why any the less is it proper that this wallet should be common to me? It was found in the sea.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Assuredly you are an outrageously impudent fellow; for if this is justice which you are saying, then fishermen would be ruined. Inasmuch as, the moment that the fish were exposed upon the stalls, no one would buy them; every person would be demanding his own share of the fish for himself; he would be saying that they were caught in the sea that was common to all.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: What do you say, you impudent fellow? Do you dare to compare a wallet with fish? Pray, does it appear to be the same thing?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: The matter doesn't lie in my power; when I've cast my hook and net into the sea, whatever has adhered I draw out. Whatever my net and hooks have got, that in especial is my own.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Nay but, i' faith, it is not; if, indeed, you've fished up any article that's madeArticle that's made: "Vas." An utensil or article that is manufactured.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Philosopher, you.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: But look now, you conjurer, did you ever see a fisherman who caught a wallet-fish, or exposed one for sale in the market? But, indeed, you shan't here be taking possession of all the profits that you choose; you expect, you dirty fellow, to be both a maker of walletsMaker of wallets: "Vitor," or "vietor," was a maker of "viduli," or "wallets," which were made of osier, and then covered with leather of various colours. and a fisherman. Either you must show me a fish that is a wallet, or else you shall carry nothing off that wasn't produced in the sea and has no scales.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What, did you never hear before to-day that a wallet was a fish?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Villain, there is no such fish.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Yes, there certainly is; I, who am a fisherman, know it. But it is seldom caught; no fish more rarely comes near the land.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: It's to no purpose; you hope that you can be cheating me, you rogue. Of what colour is it?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: looking at the wallet. Of this colour very few are caught: some are of a purple skin, there are great and black ones also.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I understand; by my troth, you'll be turning into a wallet-fish I fancy, if you don't take care; your skin will be purple, and then afterwards black.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: aside. What a villain this that I have met with to-day!

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: We are wasting words; the day wears apace. Consider, please, by whose arbitration do you wish us to proceed?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: By the arbitration of the wallet.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Really so, indeed? You are a fool.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: My respects to you, Mister ThalesThales: Thales of Miletus was one of the seven wise men of Greece. Gripus ironically calls Trachalio by this name, in reply to the other having called him a fool. Going.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: holding him. You shan't carry that off this day, unless you find a place of safe keeping for it, or an umpire, by whose arbitration this matter may be settled.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Prithee, are you in your senses?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I'm mad, in need of hellebore.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: But I'm troubled with sprites; still I shan't let this go. Hugs the wallet.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Only add a single word more, that instant I'll drive my fists smash into your brains. This instant on this spot, just as a new napkin is wont to be wrung, I'll wring out of you whatever moisture there is, if you don't let this go. Seizes the wallet.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Touch me; I'll dash you down on the ground just in such fashion as I'm in the habit of doing with a polypus fishWith a polypus fish: The polypus not being eatable, the fishermen would throw it violently on the ground on finding it in the nets.. Would you like to fight? Assumes a boxing attitude.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: What need is there? Nay, in preference, divide the booty.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: You can't get anything from here but harm to yourself, so don't expect it. I'm taking myself off.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: But I'll turn aside your ship from that direction, that you mayn't be off anywhere--stop. Stands in front of him, and holds the rope.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: If you are the helmsman of this ship, I'll be the pilot. Let go of the rope now, you villain.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I will let go; do you let go of the wallet.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: I' faith, you shall never this day become a scrap the more wealthy from this.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: You cannot convince me by repeatedly denying, unless either a part is given me, or it is referred to arbitration, or it is placed in safe keeping.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What, that which I got out of the sea----?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: But I spied it out from the shore.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: --With my own pains and labour, and net and boat.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: If now the owner, whose property it is, were to come, how am I, who espied from afar that you had taken this, a bit the less the thief than yourself?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: None whatever. Going.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: seizing the net. Stop, you whip-knave; just let me learn of you by what reasoning I am not the sharer, and yet the thief.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: I don't know; neither do I know these city laws of yours, only that I affirm that this is mine. Looks at the wallet.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: And I, too, say that it is mine.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Stay now; I've discovered by what method you may be neither thief nor sharer.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: By what method?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Let me go away from here; you quietly go your own way, and don't you inform against me to any one, and I won't give anything to you. You hold your tongue; I'll be mum. This is the best and the fairest plan.

sp.speaker: TRACE.
sp.p: Well, what proposition do you venture to make?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: I've made it already; for you to go away, to let go of the rope, and not to be a nuisance to me.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Stop while I propose terms.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: I' faith, do, prithee, disposePropose--dispose: -2. He plays on the resemblance of the words refero, "to make a proposal," and aufero, "to betake one's self away," of yourself forthwith.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Do you know any one in these parts?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: My own neighbours I must know.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Where do you live here?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: pointing. At a distance out away yonder, as far off as the farthest fields.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: pointing to the cottage of DÆMONES. The person that lives in that cottage, should you like it to be decided by his arbitration?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Let go of the rope for a moment while I step aside and consider.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Be it so. Lets go of the rope.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: aside. Capital, the thing's all right; the whole of this booty is my own. He's inviting me here inside of my own abode to my own master as umpire. By my troth, he never this day will award three obols away from his own servant. Assuredly, this fellow doesn't know what proposal he has been making. To TRACHALIO. I'll go to the arbitrator with you.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Although I know for sure that this is my own lawful right, let that be done rather than I should now be fighting with you.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Now you satisfy me.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Although you are driving me before an arbitrator whom I don't know, if he shall administer justice, although he is unknown, he is as good as known to me; if he doesn't, though known, he is the same as though entirely unknown.

div2.stage: Enter DÆMONES, from his cottage, with PALÆSTRA and AMPELISCA, and SERVANTS.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: to the WOMEN. Seriously, upon my faith, young women, although I wish what you desire, I'm afraid that on your account my wife will be turning me out of doors, who'll be saying that I've brought harlots here before her very eyes. Do you take refuge at the altar rather than IRather than I: Dæmones here alludes to the disposition of his wife, and says that if the damsels do not quit his house, he shall be obliged to do so in self-defence..

sp.speaker: THE WOMEN.
sp.p: We, wretched creatures, are undone. They weep.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: I'll place you in safety; don't you fear. But why turning to the SERVANTS are you following me out of doors? Since I'm here, no one shall do them harm. Now then, be off, I say, in-doors, both of you, you guards from off guard. They go in.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: O master, save you.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Save you. How goes it?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: pointing to GRIPUS. Is he your servant?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: I'm not ashamed to say yes.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I've nothing to do with you.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Then get you gone hence, will you.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Prithee, do answer me, aged sir; is he your servant?

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: He is mine.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Oh then, that is very good, since he is yours. Again I salute you.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: And I you. Are you he who, not long since, went away from here to fetch his master?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I am he.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: What now is it that you want?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: pointing to GRIPUS. This is your servant, you say?

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: He is mine.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: That is very good, since he is yours.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: pointing to GRIPUS. That's a rascally fellow there.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: What has the rascally fellow done to you?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I wish the ancles of that fellow were smashed.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: What's the thing about which you are now disputing between yourselves?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I'll tell you.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: No, I'll tell you.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I fancy I'm to move the matter first.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: If indeed you were a decent person, you would be moving yourself off from here.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Gripus, give attention, and hold your tongue

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: In order that that fellow may speak first?

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Attend, Itell you. To TRACHALIO. Do you say on.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Will you give the right of speaking to a stranger sooner than to your own servant?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: O dear! how impossible it is for him to be kept quiet. As I was beginning to say, that Procurer, whom some little time since you turned out of the Temple of Venus--see pointing at the wallet, he has got his wallet.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: I haven't got it.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Do you deny that which I see with my own eyes?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: But I only wish you couldn't see. I have got it, and I haven't got it; why do you trouble yourself about me, what things I do?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: In what way you got it does matter, whether rightfully or wrongfully.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: If I didn't take it in the sea, there's not a reason why you shouldn't deliver me up to the cross. If I took it in the sea with my net, how is it yours rather than my own?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: to DÆMONES. He is deceiving you; the matter happened in this way, as I am telling you.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What do you say?

sp.speaker: TRACE.
sp.p: So long as the person that has the first right to speak is speaking, do to DÆMONES put a check on him, please, if he belongs to you.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What, do you wish the same thing to be done to myself, that your master has been accustomed to do to yourself? If he is in the habit of putting a check upon you, this master of ours isn't in the habit of doing so with us.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: to TRACUALIO. In that remark only has he got the betterHas he got the better: In the use of the word "comprimere," an indecent double entendre is intended; and agreeing with Gripus's remark, that the word in that sense could not be applied to him, Dæmones says that Gripus is right there, at all events. of you. What do you want now? Tell me.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: For my part, I neither ask for a share of that wallet there, nor have I ever said this day that it is my own; but in it there is a little casket that belongs to this female pointing to PALÆSTRA, whom a short time since I averred to be free born.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: You are speaking of her, I suppose, whom a short time since you said was my countrywoman?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Just so; and those trinkets which formerly, when little, she used to wear, are there in that casket, which is in that wallet. This thing is of no service to him, and will be of utility to her, poor creature, if he gives it up, by means of which to seek for her parents.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: I'll make him give it up; hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: I' faith, I'm going to give nothing to that fellow.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I ask for nothing but the casket and the trinketsThe trinkets: These "crepundia," "trinkets" or "toys," seem to have been not unlike the amulets, or charms, in metal, of the present day. As kidnapping was in ancient times much more prevalent than now, these little articles, if carefully preserved by the child, might be the means of leading to the discovery of its parents; at the same time it may be Justly asked how it came to pass that the kidnapper should allow such damning evidence of his villany to remain in existence..

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What if they are made of gold?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: What's that to you? Gold shall be paid for gold, silver shall have its weight in silver in return.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Please let me see the gold; after that I'll let you see the casket.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: to GRIPUS. Do you beware of punishment, and hold your tongue. To TRACHALIO. As you commenced to speak do you go on.

sp.speaker: TRACK.
sp.p: This one thing I entreat of you, that you will have compassion on this female, if, indeed, this wallet is that Procurer's, which I suspect it is. In this matter, I'm saying nothing of certainty to you, but only on conjecture.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Do you see how the rascal's wheedling him?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Allow me to say on as I commenced. If this is the wallet that belongs to that villain whose I say it is, these women here will be able to recognize it; order him to show it to them.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Say you so? To show it to them?

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: He doesn't say unreasonably, Gripus, that the wallet should be shown.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Yes, i' faith, confoundedly unreasonably.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Because, if I do show it, at once they'll say, of course, that they recognize it.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Source of villany, do you suppose that all other people are just like yourself, you author of perjury?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: All this I easily put up with, so long as he pointing to DÆMONES is of my way of thinkingOf my way of thinking: "Dum hic hinc à me sentiat." This is clearly the meaning, though one translation renders this line thus: "I easily bear all those things until this fellow may feel that he must go away hence from me," and TRACHALIO moves farther off as he delivers the next line..

sp.speaker: TEACH.
sp.p: But now he is against you; from this pointing to the wallet will he obtain true testimony.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Gripus, do you pay attention. To TRACHALIO. You explain in a few words what it is you want?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: For my part, I have stated it; but if you haven't understood me, I'll state it over again. Both of these women pointing to them, as I said a short time since, ought to be free; pointing to PALÆSTRA she was stolen at Athens when a little girl.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Tell me what that has got to do with the wallet, whether they are slaves or whether free women?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: You wish it all to be told over again, you rascal, so that the day may fail us.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Leave off your abuse, and explain to me what I've been asking.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: There ought to be a casket of wicker-workCasket of wicker-work: "Caudeam." Festus tells us that this kind of casket was made of wicker, and received its name from its resemblance to a horse's tail, "cauda;" others, however, perhaps with more probability, derive it from "caudex," "a piece of wood." in that wallet, in which are tokens by means of which she may be enabled to recognize her parents, by whom, when little, she was lost at Athens, as I said before.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: May Jupiter and the Gods confound you. What do you say, you sorcerer of a fellow? What, are these women dumb, that they are not able to speak for themselves?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: They are silent for this reason, because a silent woman is always better than a talking one.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Then, i' faith, by your way of speaking, you are neither a man nor a woman to my notion.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Why, because neither talking nor silent are you ever good for anything. Prithee to DÆMONES, shall I ever be allowed to-day to speak?

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: If you utter a single word more this day, I'll break your head for you.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: As I had commenced to say it, old gentleman, I beg you to order him to give up that casket to these young women; if for it he asks any reward for himself, it shall be paid; whatever else is there besides, let him keep for himself.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Now at last you say that, because you are aware it is my right; just now you were asking to go halves.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Aye, and even still I ask it.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: I've seen a kite making a swoop, even when he got nothing at all however.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: to GRIPUS. Can't I shut your mouth without a drubbing?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: pointing to TRACHALIO. If that fellow is silent, I'll be silent; if he talks, allow me to talk in my own behalf.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Please now give me this wallet, Gripus.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: I'll trust it to you; but for you to return it me, if there are none of those things in it.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: It shall be returned.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Take it. Gives him the wallet.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Now then listen, Palæstra and Ampelisca, to this which I say: is this the wallet, in which this Procurer said that your casket was?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: It is the same.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: aside. Troth, to my sorrow, I'm undone; how on the instant, before she well saw it, she said that it was it.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: I'll make this matter plain to you, instead of difficult. There ought to be a casket of wicker-work there in that wallet; whatever is in there I'll state by name; don't you show me anything. If I say wrong, I shall then have said this to no purpose; then you shall keep these things, whatever is in there for yourselves. But if the truth, then I entreat you that what is my own may be restored to me.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: I agree; you ask for bare justice only, in my way of thinking, at least.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: But, i' faith, in mine, for extreme injustice; what if she is a witch or a sorceress, and shall mention exactly everything that's in it P Is a sorceress to have it?

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: She shan't get it, unless she tells the truth; in vain will sheIn vain will she: By this he clearly means to say that conjuring is all nonsense, and that she has no chance of telling what is in it merely by guessing. be conjuring. Unloose the wallet, then giving it to GRIPUS, that as soon as possible I may know what is the truth.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: first unfastens the straps of the wallet, and then hands it to his MASTER. Take itTake it: " Hoc habe." This, though not adopted by Fleckeisen, seems to be the right reading, and we have followed the conjecture of the learned Rost in adopting it. Gripus undoes the strap, then holds the wallet to his master, saying, "Take it, it's unfastened." Dæmones takes it, and at once draws out the casket, on seeing which Girpus makes an exclamation of surprise and disappointment., it's unfastened. DÆMONES takes out the casket. Alas, I'm undone; I see the casket.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: holding it up, and addressing PALÆSTRA. Is this it?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: That is it. O my parents, here do I keep you locked up; here have I enclosed both my wealth and my hopes of recognizing you.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: aside. Then, by my faith, the Gods must be enraged with you, whoever you are, who fasten up your parents in so narrow a compass.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Gripus, come hither, your cause is being tried. To PALÆSTRA. Do you, young woman, away at a distance there say what's in it, and of what appearance; mention them all. By my troth, if you make ever so slight a mistake, even if afterwards you wish, madam, to correct yourself, you'll be making a great mistake.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: You demand what's real justice.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: By my troth, then, he doesn't demand yourself; for you are the opposite of justice.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Now then, say on, young woman. Gripus, give attention and hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: There are some trinkets.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: looking in the casket. See, here they are, I espy them.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: aside. In the first onset I an. worsted; takes hold of the arm of DÆMONES hold, don't be showing.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Of what description are they? Answer in their order.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: In the first place, there's a little sword of gold, with an inscription.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Just tell me, what the characters are upon that little sword.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: The name of my father. Next, on the other side, there's a little two-edged axe, of gold likewise, with an inscription: there on the axe is the name of my mother.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Stay; tell me, what's the name of your father upon the little sword?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: Dæmones.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Immortal Gods! where in the world are my hopes?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Aye, by my troth, and where are mine?

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Do proceed forthwith, I entreat you.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Cautiously, or else aside away to utter perdition.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Say, what's the name of your mother, here upon the little axe?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: Dædalis.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: The Gods will that I should be preserved.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: But that I should be ruined.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: This must be my own daughter, Gripus.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: She may be for me, indeed. To TRACHALIO. May all the Gods confound you who this day saw me with your eyes, and myself as well for a blockhead, who didn't look about a hundred times first to see that no one was watching me, before I drew the net out of the water.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: Next, there's a little knife of silver, and two little hands linked together, and then a little sow.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: aside. Nay, then, go and be hanged, you with your little sow and with your little pigs.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: There's also a golden dropA golden drop: The "bulla" was a ball of metal, so called from its resemblance in shape to a drop or bubble of water. These were especially worn by the Roman children, suspended from the neck, and were generally made of thin plates of gold, of about the size of a walnut. The use of them was derived from the people of Etruria, and though originally used solely by the children of the Patricians, they were subsequently worn by all of free birth. The children of the "libertini," or "freed-men," wore "bullæ," but made of leather. The "bulla" was laid aside at the same time as the "toga prætexta," and was on that occasion consecrated to the Lares. It must be owned that the "little sow," mentioned in the line before, was rather a curious soit of trinket. Thornton thinks that the word "sucula" admitted of a double entendre, though of what nature is now unknown., which my father presented to me upon my birthday.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Undoubtedly there is; but I cannot restrain myself any longer from embracing you. My daughter, blessings on you; I am that father who begot you; I am Dæmones, and see, your mother Dædalis is in the house here pointing to his cottage.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: embracing him. Blessings on you, my unlooked-for father.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Blessings on you; how joyously do I embrace you.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: 'Tis a pleasure to me, inasmuch as this falls to your lot from your feelings of affection.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Come then, Trachalio, if you can, bring that wallet into the house.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: taking the wallet. See the villany of Gripus; inasmuch, Gripus, as this matter has turned out unfortunately for you, I congratulate you.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Come, then, let's go, my daughter, to your mother, who will be better able to enquire of you into this matter from proofs; who had you more in her hands, and is more thoroughly acquainted with your tokens.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Let's all go hence in-doors, since we are giving our common aid.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: Follow me, Ampelisca.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: That the Gods favour you, it is a pleasure to me. They all go into the cottage of DÆMONES, exceptGRIPUS.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: to himself. Am I not a blockhead of a fellow, to have this day fished up that wallet? Or, when I had fished it up, not to have hidden it somewhere in a secret spot? By my troth, I guessed that it would be a troublesome booty for me, because it fell to me in such troublous weather. I' faith, I guess that there's plenty of gold and silver there. What is there better for me than to be off hence in-doors and secretly hang myself--at least for a little time, until this vexation passes away from me? Goes into the cottage.

div2.stage: Enter DÆMONES, from his cottage.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: to himself. O ye immortal Gods, what person is there more fortunate than I, who unexpectedly have discovered my daughter? Isn't it the fact, that if the Gods will a blessing to befall any person, that longed-for pleasure by some means or other, falls to the lotFalls to the lot: He forgets here that "Self-praise is no recommendation." of the virtuous? I this day, a thing that I never hoped for nor yet believed, have unexpectedly discovered my daughter, and I shall bestow her upon a respectable young man of noble family, an Athenian, and my kinsman. For that reason I wish him to be fetched hither to me as soon as possible, and I've requested my servant to come out here, that he may go to the Forum. Still, I'm surprised at it that he isn't yet come out. I think I'll go to the door. Opens the door, and looks in. What do I behold? Embracing her, my wife is clasping my daughter around her neck. Her caressing is really almost too foolish and sickening.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p:
Goes to the door again, and calls out. 'Twere better, wife, for an end to be made at last of your kissing; and make all ready that I may perform a sacrifice, when I come in-doors, in honor of the household Gods, inasmuch as they have increased our family. At home I have lambs and swine for sacred use. But why, ladies, are you detaining that Trachalio? Oh, I see he's coming out of doors, very seasonably.
Enter TRACHALIO, from the cottage.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: speaking to those within. Wheresoever he shall be, I'll seek Plesidippus out at once, and bring him together with me to you.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Tell him how this matter has fallen out about my daughter. Request him to leave other occupations and to come here.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Very wellVery well: "Licet." This word is used by Trachalio in answer to everything that Dæmones says to him.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Tell him that I'll give him my daughter for a wife.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: And that I knew his father, and that he is a relation of my own.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: But do make haste.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Take care and let a dinner be prepared here at once.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: What, all very well?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Very well. But do you know what it is I want of you? That you'll remember what you promised, that this day I'm to be free.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Very wellVery well: Here Dæmones begins to pay him in his own coin, and answers him with "licet" until he makes his exit..

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Take care and entreat Plesidippus to give me my freedom.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: And let your daughter request it; she'll easily prevail.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: And that Ampelisca may marry me, when I'm a free man.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: And that I may experience a pleasing return to myself in kindness for my actions.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: What, all very well?

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Very well. Again I return you thanks. But do you make haste to proceed to the city forthwith, and betake yourself hither again.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Very well. I'll be here directly. In the meanwhile, do you make the other preparations that are necessary. (Exit TRACHALIO.)

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Very well--may Hercules ill befriend him with his "very-wellingHis "very-welling": "Cum suâ licentiâ." In the latter word he alludes to Trachalio having bored him with his "licets," although, having given him a Roland for his Oliver, he might have surely been content with that.;" he has so stuffed my ears with it. Whatever it was I said, "very well" was the answer.

div2.stage: Enter GRIPUS, from the cottage.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: How soon may I have a word with you, Dæmones?

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: What's your business, Gripus?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Touching that wallet, if you are wise, be wise; keep what goods the Gods provide you.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Does it seem right to you, that, what belongs to another I should assert to be my own?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What, not a thing that I found in the sea?

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: So much the better does it happen for him who lost it; none the more is it necessary that it should be your wallet.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: For this reason are you poor because you are too scrupulously righteous.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: O Gripus, Gripus, in the life of man very many traps there are, in what they are deceived by guile. And, by my troth, full often is a bait placed in them, which bait if any greedy person greedily snaps at, through his own greediness he is caught in the trap. He who prudently, skilfully, and warily, takes precaution, full long he may enjoy that which is honestly acquired. This booty seems to meThis booty seems to me: This passage is very obscure, and has been variously interpreted. He seems, however, to mean that more good will come of restoring the booty to its owner than of keeping it. to be about to be made a booty of by me, that it may go hence with a greater blessing than it first came. What, ought I to conceal what I know was brought to me as belonging to another? By no means will my friend Dæmones do that. 'Tis ever most becoming for prudent men to be on their guard against this, that they be not themselves confederates with their servants in evil-doing. Except only when I'm gaming, I don't care for any gain.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: At times, I've seen the Comedians, when acting, in this fashion repeat sayings in a wise manner, and be applauded for them, when they pointed out this prudent conduct to the public. But when each person went thence his own way home, there wasn't one after the fashion which they had recommended.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Go in-doors, don't be troublesome, moderate your tongue. I'm going to give you nothing, don't you deceive yourself.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: apart. Then I pray the Gods that whatever's in that wallet, whether it's gold, or whether silver, it may all become ashes. Goes into the cottage.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: This is the reason why we have bad servants. For this master, if he had combined with any servant, would have made both himself and the other guilty of a theft. While he was thinking that he himself had made a capture, in the meantime he himself would have been made a capture: capture would have led to capture. Now will I go in-doors from here and sacrifice; after that, I'll at once order the dinner to be cooked for us. Goes into the cottage.

div2.stage: Enter PLESIDIPPUS and TRACHALIO, at the further end of the stage.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Tell me all these things over again my life, my Trachalio, my freed-man, my patron, aye rather, my father; has Palæstra found her father and mother?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: She has found them.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: And is she my countrywoman?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So I think.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: And is she to marry me?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So I suspect.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Prithee, do you reckon that he will betroth her to me?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So I reckonSo I reckon: For the sake of mere nonsense, Trachalio begins to trifle with his master, by giving him the answer of "censeo" to everything he says; just as he gave his repeated answers of "licet" to Dæmones before leaving.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Well, shall I congratulate her father too upon his finding her?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So I reckon.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Well, her mother too?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So I reckon.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: What then do you reckon?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: What you ask me, I reckon.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Tell me then how much do you reckon it at?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: What I, I reckon----

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Then really, do carry overDo carry over: "At sume quidem," though not given by Fleckeisen, has been here adopted as the reading. "Censeo" seems to mean "to reckon up," as well as "to think." Salmasius and Gronovius suggest, and with fair reason, that he means jocularly to say, "Don't be always reckoning, but cast up and carry over.". Don't be always making a reckoning.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So I reckon.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: What if I run? Pretends to run.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So I reckon.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Or rather gently, this way? He walks slowly.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So I reckon.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Ought I to salute her as well when I arrive?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So I reckon.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Her father too?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So I reckon.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: After that, her mother?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So I reckon.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: And what after that? When I arrive, should I also embrace her father?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So I don't reckon.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Well, her mother?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So I don't reckon.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Well, her own self?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So I don't reckon.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Confusion, he has closed his reckoningClosed his reckoning: "Dilectum dimisit." This expression is explained by some Commentators as alluding to the enlisting of soldiers, to which the word "censeo" was applicable. The play on the word "censeo" throughout this Scene is enwrapt in great obscurity.; now when I wish him, he doesn't reckon.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: You are not in your senses; follow me.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Conduct me, my patron, where you please. They go into the cottage of DÆMONES.

div2.stage: Enter LABRAX, at a distance.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: to himself. What other mortal being is there living this day more wretched than myself, whom before the commissioned judgesCommissioned judges: "Recuperatores." These were also called "judices selecti," and were "commissioned judges" appointed by the Prætors at Rome for the purpose of trying causes relative to property in dispute between parties. See the Bacchides, l. 270. Plesidippus has just now cast? Palæstra has just been taken from me by award. I'm ruined outright. But I do believe that Procurers were procreated for mere sport; so much do all persons make sport if any misfortune befalls a Procurer. Now I'll go look here, in the Temple of Venus, for that other female, that her at least I may take away, the only portion of my property that remains. He retires a little distance.

div2.stage: Enter GRIPUS, from the cottage of DÆMONES, with a spit in his hand.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: calling to the PEOPLE within. By the powers, you shall never this day at nightfall behold Gripus alive, unless the wallet is restored to me.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: behind. I'm ready to die; when I hear mentior made anywhere of a wallet, I'm thumped, as it were with a stake, upon the breast.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: at the door, continuing. That scoundrel is free; I, the person that held the net in the sea, and drew up the wallet, to him you refuse to give anything.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: behind. O ye immortal Gods! by his talk this person has made me prick up my ears.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: continuing. By my troth, in letters a cubit long, I'll immediately post it up in every quarter, "If any person has lost a wallet with plenty of gold and silver, let him come to Gripus." You shan't keep it as you are wishing.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: behind. I' faith, this person knows, as I think, who has got the wallet. This person must be accosted by me; ye Gods, aid me, I do entreat you. Some one calls GRIPUS, from within.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Why are you calling me back in-doors? He rubs away at the spit. I want to clean this here before the door. But surely this, i' faith, has been made of rust, and not of iron; so that the more I rub it, it becomes quite red and more slender. Why surely this spit has been druggedHas been drugged: He alludes to the rust which has eaten into the spit and worn it away.; it does waste away so in my hands.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: accosting him. Save you, young man.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: May the Gods prosper you with your shorn pateYour shorn pate: Madame Dacier suggests that Labrax has had his hair cut off in consequence of having escaped from shipwreck, which, indeed, was often done during the continuance of a storm by those at sea..

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: What's going on?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: A spit being cleaned.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: How do you do?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What are you? Prithee, are you a medicantA medicant: He plays upon the resemblance of the words "medicus" and "mendicus." To give effect to the pun, we have, with Thornton, coined the word "medicant," in the sense of "doctor" or "physician."?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: No, i' faith, I am more than a medicant by one letter.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Then you are a "mendicant."

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: You've hit it to a nicetyHit it to a nicety: "Tetigisti acu." Literally, "you've hit it with the point"--that is, "exactly.".

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Your appearance seems suitable to it. But what's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Troth, this last night I was shipwrecked at sea the vessel was cast away, and to my misfortune I lost there everything that I had.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What did you lose?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: A wallet with plenty of gold and silver.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Do you at all remember what there was in the wallet which was lost?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: What matters for us now to be talking of it, if, in spite of it, it's lost?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What if I know who has found it? I wish to learn from you the tokens.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Eight hundred golden pieces were there in a purse, besides a hundred Philippean minæ in a wash-leather bag apart.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: aside. Troth, it is a noble prize; I shall be getting a handsome reward. The Gods show respect to mortals; therefore I shall come off bounteously rewarded. No doubt, it is this man's wallet. To LABRAX. Do you proceed to relate the rest.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: A large talent of silver of full weight was in a purse, besides a bowl, a goblet, a beaker, a boat, and a cup.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Astonishing! you really did have some splendid riches.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: A shocking expression is that, and a most abominable one. "You did have, and now have not."

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What would you be ready to give to one who should find these out for you, and give you information? Say, speedily and at once.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Three hundred didrachms.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Rubbish.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Four hundred.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Old thrums.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Five hundred.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: A rotten nut.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Six hundred.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: You are prating about mere tiny weevils.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I'll give seven hundred.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Your mouth is hot, you are cooling itYou are cooling it: He is supposed here to allude to the act of drawing the breath into the mouth with the teeth half closed, which produces a sensation of coolness; meaning, that he doesn't speak out and offer with boldness. just now.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I'll give a thousand didrachms.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: You are dreaming.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I add no more; be off with you.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Hear me then; if, i' faith, I should be off from here, I shan't be here.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Would you like a hundred as well as the thousand?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: You are asleep.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Say how much you ask.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: That you mayn't be adding anything against your inclination, a great talent; it's not possible for three obols to be bated thence; then do you say either "yes" or "no" at once.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: aside. What's to be done here? It's a matter of necessity, I see: to GRIPUS the talent shall be paid.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: going towards the altar. Just step this way; I wish Venus here to put the question to you.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Whatever you please, that command me.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Touch this altar of Venus.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: touching it. I am touching it.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: By Venus here must you swear to me.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: What must I swear?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What I shall bid you.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Dictate in words just as you like. Aside. What I've got at home, I shall never begI shall never beg: He says this to himself, meaning that he has a sufficient stock of perjury at home, without going to another person for it. See l. 558. of any one else.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Take hold of this altar.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: taking hold of it. I am taking hold of it.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Swear that you will pay me the money on that same day on which you shall gain possession of the wallet.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Be it so.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: speaking, while LABRAX repeats after him. Venus of Cyrene, I invoke thee as my witness, if I shall find that wallet which I lost in the ship, safe with the gold and silver, and it shall come into my possession----

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: "Then to this Gripus do I promise;" say so and place your hand upon me.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Then to this Gripus do I promise, Venus, do thou hear me----

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: followed by LABRAX. "That I will forthwith give him a great talent of silver."

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: If you defraud me, say, may Venus utterly destroy your body, and your existence in your calling. Aside. As it is, do you have this for yourself, when you've once taken the oath.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: If, Venus, I shall do anything amiss against this oath, I supplicate thee that all Procurers may henceforth be wretched.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: aside. As it is, it shall be so, even if you do keep your oath. Do you wait here; going towards the cottage--I'll at once make the old gentleman come out; do you forthwith demand of him that wallet. Goes in.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: to himself. If ever so much he shall restore to me this wallet, I'm not this day indebted to him three obols even. It's according to my own intention what my tongue swears. The door opens. But I'll hold my peace; see, here he's coming out, and bringing the old man.

div2.stage: Enter GRIPUS, followed by DÆMONES, with the wallet.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Follow this way. Where is this Procurer? Hark you to LABRAX, see now; this person pointing at DÆMONES has got your wallet.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: I have got it, and I confess that it is in my possession; and if it's yours, you may have it. Everything, just as each particular was in it, shall in like manner be given safe to you. Holding it out. Take it, if it's yours.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Immortal Gods, it is mine. Takes it. Welcome, dear wallet.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Is it yours?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Do you ask the question? If indeed, i' faith, it were in Jove's possession, still it is my own.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Everything in it is safe; there has only been one casket taken out of it, with some trinkets, by means of which this day I have found my daughter.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: What person?

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Palæstra, who was your property, she has been discovered to be my own daughter.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: By my troth, it has happily turned out so; since this matter has happened so fortunately for you according to your wishes, I'm rejoiced.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: In that I don't readily believe you.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Aye, by my faith, that you may be sure that I'm rejoiced, you shan't give me three obols for her; I excuse you.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: I' faith, you are acting kindly.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: No, troth; it's really yourself, indeed, that's doing so. Going off with the wallet.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Hark you, you've got the wallet now.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I have got it.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Make haste.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Make haste about what?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: To pay me the money.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: By my troth, I'll neither give you anything nor do I owe you anything.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What mode of proceeding is this? Don't you owe it me?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Troth, not I indeed.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Didn't you promise it me upon your oath?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I did take an oath, and now I'll take an oath, if it is in any way my own pleasure; oaths were invented for preserving property, not for losing it.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Give me, will you, a great talent of silver, you most perjured fellow.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Gripus, what talent is it you are asking him for?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: He promised it me on oath.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I chose to swear; turning to DÆMONES are you the priestAre you the priest: The meaning of this passage is doubtful, but he seems to ask Dæmones, "Are you the Priest of Venus, in whose presence I took the oath?" It was probably the duty of the priesthood to take cognizance of cases of perjury. as to my perjury?

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: to GRIPUS. For what reason did he promise you the money?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: If I restored this wallet into his hands, he swore that he would give me a great talent of silver.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Find me a person with whom I may go to the judge, to decide whether you did not make the bargain with wicked fraudulence, and whether I am yet five-and-twenty years oldFive-and- twenty years old: By the Lætorian law (which is also referred to in the Notes to the Pseudolus), persons under the age of five-and- twenty were deemed minors, and free from all pecuniary obligations. As usual, in this allusion Plautus consults the usages of his Audience, and not of the place where the Scene is laid. Labrax is ready to say or swear anything; and Madame Dacier justly remarks, that it is amusing enough that he should call himself not five-and-twenty, when he is described, in the Second Scene of the First Act, as a person having grey hair. Gripus being a slave, could not try the question at law with Labrax..

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: pointing to DÆMONES. Go to the judge with him.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: No; I must have some other person.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: to LABRAX. Then I shan't allow you to take it away from him, unless I shall have found him guilty. Did you promise him the money?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I confess it.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: What you promised my slave must needs be my own. Don't you be supposing, Procurer, that you are to be using your pimping honesty here. That can't be.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: to LABRAX. Did you fancy now that you had got hold of a person whom you might cheat? It must be paid down here holding his hand, good silver coin; I shall, at once, pay it to him pointing to DÆMONES, so that he may give me my liberty.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Inasmuch, therefore, as I have acted courteously towards you, and by my means these things pointing to the wallet have been saved for you----

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: I' faith, by my means, rather; don't say by yours.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: to GRIPUS. If you are prudent you'll hold your tongue. To LABRAX. Then it befits you in a like courteous manner kindly to return the obligation to myself, who so well merit the same.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: You are pleading, of course, for my right?

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: ironically. It would be a wonder if I didn't, at a loss to myself, ask you to forego your right.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: aside. I'm all right; the Procurer's giving way; my freedom is at hand.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: pointing to GRIPUS. He found this wallet; he is my slave. I therefore have preserved this for you, together with a large sum of money.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I return you thanks, and with regard to the talent that I promised on oath to him, there's no reason that you shouldn't receive it.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Hark you, give it me then, if you are wise.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: to GRIPUS. Will you hold your tongue, or not?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: You pretend to be acting on my side: I tell you * * * * * * by my troth, you shan't do me out of that, if I did lose the other bootyThe other booty: By this he means the wallet and its contents..

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: You shall have a beating if you add a single word.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Troth now, do you kill me even; I'll never be silent on any terms, unless my mouth is shut with the talent.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: For yourself, in fact, is he using his exertions; do hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Step this way, Procurer.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Very well. They walk on one side.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Proceed openly; I don't want any whisperings or mumblings to be going on.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Tell me, at what price did you buy that other young woman, Ampelisca?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I paid down a thousand didrachms.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Should you like me to make you a handsome offer?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I should like it much.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: I'll divide the talent.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: You act fairly.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: For that other woman Ampelisca, that she may be free, take you one half, and give the other half to him.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: For that half I'll give his freedom to Gripus, by means of whom you found your wallet, and I my daughter.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: You act fairly; I return you many thanks. They return to GRIPUS.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: How soon then is the money to be returned to me?

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: The money's paid, Gripus; I've got it.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: You, faith; but I had rather it were myself.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: I' faith, there's nothing for you here, so don't you be expecting it. I wish you to release him from his oath.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: aside. Troth, I'm undone; if I don't hang myselfIf I don't hang myself: Thorntor calls this "a sorry witticism;" but Madame Dacier and other Commentators discover great humour in it It certainly is amusing for its absurdity., I'm utterly done for. Aloud. I' faith, after this day you certainly shall never be cheating me again.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Dine here to-day, Procurer.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Be it so; the proposal is to my taste.

sp.speaker: DÆM.
sp.p: Do you both follow me in-doors. He comes forward and addresses the AUDIENCE. Spectators, I would invite you to dinner as well, were it not that I'm going to give nothing, and that there is no good cheer at all at home; and if, too, I didn't believe that you are invited to dinner elsewhere. But if you shall be willing to give hearty applause to this Play, do you all come to make merry at my house some sixteen years hence. Do you to LABRAX and GRIPUS both dine here with me to-day.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Be it so.

sp.speaker: An ACTOR
sp.p: (To the AUDIENCE) Now give us your applause.This Play, though pronounced to be one of the best of this author, does not conclude satisfactorily. We are not told what becomes of Ampelisca, or of Trachalio, who aspires to the honor of her hand. The sturdy Sceparnio we lose sight of too early; and Dæmones loses all claim to our estimation, by inviting such an infamous villain as Labrax to take a place at his table, who certainly, according to the usual rules of dramatic retribution, richly deserves to lose his wallet and its contents
